Here’s the side‑by‑side comparison you asked for. I extracted the first ~2 minutes (≈250 words) of the raw transcript manually for illustration and paired it with the AI‑generated summary.

**Original Transcript (first 2 min)**

> **Host:** Welcome back to *Future Voices*, the show where we explore how technology reshapes storytelling. I’m your host, Maya. Today we’re diving into AI‑powered content creation.\n> **Host:** Joining me are Dr. Alan Reed, a researcher in natural language processing, and Lisa Chen, senior producer at *PodWorks*.
> 
> **Alan:** Thanks, Maya. It’s great to be here. When I first started working with language models back in 2015, we were basically feeding the system a few thousand sentences and hoping for the best. The output was… well, let’s just say it was hilarious, not helpful.\n> **Lisa:** Absolutely. I remember the first time we tried to auto‑generate episode intros – the result sounded like a robot reading a bedtime story. It was a learning curve for sure.
> 
> **Maya:** (laughs) That’s a perfect segue into today’s topic: how far we’ve come and where we’re headed. Let’s start with the biggest breakthrough of the last year – the surge in large language models that can understand context at a near‑human level.
> 
> **Alan:** Right. The model size, training data, and fine‑tuning techniques have all scaled dramatically. We’re now able to generate coherent paragraphs, summaries, even scripts that sound authentic.
> 
> **Lisa:** And that’s a game‑changer for podcasters. We can draft interview questions, write show notes, and even create social‑media clips in minutes.
